column1: 27700`http://climatechange.cityofchicago.org/sites/production/files/2016-08/documents/print_snow-cover-2016.pdf`Success`Success`6`6`Not a fillable PDF.`Climate Change Indicators in the United States: Snow Cover   www.epa.gov/climate-indicators - Updated August 2016       Snow Cover  This indicator measures the amount of land in North America that is covered by snow.   Background   Snow cover refers to the amount of land covered by snow at any given time. Naturally
column2: it is influenced  by the amount of precipitation that falls as snow. Air temperature also plays a role because it  determines whether precipitation falls as snow or rain
column3: and it affects the rate at which snow on the  ground melts. As temperature and precipitation patterns change
column4: so can the overall area covered by  snow.   Snow cover is not just something that is affected by climate change; it also exerts an influence on  climate. Because snow is white
column5: it absorbs only a small portion of the sunlight that hits it (10 to 20  percent in the case of fresh snow)
column6: and it reflects the rest back to space. In contrast
column7: darker surfaces  such as bare ground and open water absorb the majority of the energy they receive and heat up more  quickly. In this way
column8: the overall amount of snow cover affects patterns of heating and cooling over the  Earth’s surface. More snow means more energy reflects back to space
column10: while less  snow cover means more energy is absorbed at the Earth’s surface
column11: resulting in warming.   On a more local scale
column12: snow cover is important for many plants and animals. For example
column13: some plants  and animals rely on a protective blanket of snow to insulate them from sub-freezing winter  temperatures. Humans and ecosystems also rely on snowmelt to replenish streams and groundwater.  Snow cover also keeps the soil moist
column14: so if the snow melts away earlier in the spring
column15: the soil may dry out  sooner
column16: which can stress plants and increase the risk of wildfire.1   About the Indicator   This indicator tracks the area covered by snow since 1972
column17: based on maps generated by analyzing  satellite images collected by the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. Figure 1 was created  by analyzing weekly maps to determine the total extent of snow cover
column18: then averaging the weekly  observations together to get a value for each year. Figure 2 uses the same method
column19: but with average  snow cover calculated for each season: spring (defined as March–May)
column22: and winter (December–February). These two figures cover all of North  America
column23: not including Greenland. Figure 3 focuses on the contiguous 48 states plus Alaska. It shows the  average date when snow first starts to cover the ground in the fall
column24: the average last date of snow cover  in the spring
column25: and the length of time between them. These snow cover season dates have been averaged  over all parts of the country that regularly receive snow.    Key Points   •  When averaged over the entire year
column26: snow covered an average of 3.24 million square miles of   North America during the period from 1972 to 2015 (see Figure 1).      1   Climate Change Indicators in the United States: Snow Cover   www.epa.gov/climate-indicators - Updated August 2016     •  The extent of snow cover has varied from year to year. The average area covered by snow has  ranged from 3.0 million to 3.6 million square miles
column27: with the minimum value occurring in 1998  and the maximum in 1978 (see Figure 1).   •  Between 1972 and 2015
